<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 119, 379, 144]]<|/det|> # Cambridge IGCSE™ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 195, 201]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NAME <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 221, 175, 250]]<|/det|> CENTRE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 210, 425, 256]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 220, 720, 250]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[735, 210, 905, 255]]<|/det|> <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 277, 178, 293]]<|/det|> ## PHYSICS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 293]]<|/det|> 0625/52 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 260, 316]]<|/det|> Paper 5 Practical Test <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|> October/November 2021 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 325, 905, 341]]<|/det|> 1 hour 15 minutes <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 371]]<|/det|> You must answer on the question paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 700, 401]]<|/det|> You will need: The materials and apparatus listed in the confidential instructions <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|> ## INSTRUCTIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 560]]<|/det|> INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units. <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 603]]<|/det|> ## INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 605, 729, 636]]<|/det|> INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ]. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 644, 905, 839]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
Another student wants to obtain a more accurate value for \(V_{1}\). He uses the method of floating the block of wood in water as described in **(b)**.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 875, 135]]<|/det|>
Suggest how the student could obtain a more accurate value by taking a measurement.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 148, 601, 166]]<|/det|>
You are **not** required to do this part of the experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 274, 920, 291]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 97, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 767, 91]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the resistances of a resistor and a lamp.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 771, 121]]<|/det|>
Fig. 2.1 shows the first circuit arrangement. The circuit has been set up for you.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[270, 129, 727, 355]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[462, 370, 532, 388]]<|/det|>
<mark>[b]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 401, 144, 420]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 401, 245, 420]]<|/det|>
Switch on.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 432, 183, 451]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 432, 680, 451]]<|/det|>
Record \(V_{\mathrm{S}}\), the potential difference (p.d.) across resistor R.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[569, 462, 920, 482]]<|/det|>
<form>V<sub>S</sub> = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 494, 181, 513]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 494, 792, 513]]<|/det|>
Record \(I_{\mathrm{S}}\), the current in the circuit and then switch off the power supply.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[571, 523, 920, 544]]<|/det|>
<form>I<sub>S</sub> = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 572, 180, 590]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 562, 777, 592]]<|/det|>
Calculate \(R_{\mathrm{S}}\), the resistance of resistor R, using the equation \(R_{\mathrm{S}} = \frac{V_{\mathrm{S}}}{I_{\mathrm{S}}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[566, 632, 920, 653]]<|/det|>
<form>R_{\mathrm{S}} = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 663, 144, 682]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[178, 664, 406, 682]]<|/det|>
Disconnect the voltmeter.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 694, 181, 712]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 694, 482, 712]]<|/det|>
Replace the resistor with the lamp.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 725, 180, 744]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 725, 520, 744]]<|/det|>
Connect the voltmeter across the lamp.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 757, 285, 775]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 757, 284, 775]]<|/det|>
Switch on.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 788, 183, 807]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 788, 621, 807]]<|/det|>
Record \(V_{\mathrm{L}}\), the potential difference across the lamp.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[576, 819, 918, 838]]<|/det|>
<form>V<sub>L</sub> = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 850, 789, 868]]<|/det|>
Record \(I_{\mathrm{L}}\), the current in the circuit and then switch off the power supply.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[576, 880, 920, 900]]<|/det|>
<form>I<sub>L</sub> = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 897, 920, 915]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 78, 181, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 69, 771, 102]]<|/det|>
Calculate \(R_{\mathrm{L}}\), the resistance of the lamp, using the equation \(R_{\mathrm{L}} = \frac{V_{\mathrm{L}}}{I_{\mathrm{L}}}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[569, 139, 920, 161]]<|/det|>
<form>R_{\mathrm{L}} = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 172, 144, 191]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 171, 405, 191]]<|/det|>
Disconnect the voltmeter.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 202, 180, 220]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 201, 576, 221]]<|/det|>
Connect the resistor R in series with the lamp.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 234, 176, 252]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 232, 920, 268]]<|/det|>
Connect the voltmeter to record \(V_{\mathrm{C}}\), the potential difference across the series combination of the resistor and the lamp.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 280, 181, 299]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 280, 574, 299]]<|/det|>
Draw the circuit diagram for this arrangement.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 621, 920, 640]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 650, 181, 670]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 650, 920, 670]]<|/det|>
Switch on. Record \(V_{\mathrm{C}}\), the potential difference across the resistor and the lamp in series.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[569, 681, 920, 701]]<|/det|>
<form>V_{\mathrm{C}} = ..........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 712, 792, 732]]<|/det|>
Record \(I_{\mathrm{C}}\), the current in the circuit and then switch off the power supply.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[571, 743, 920, 764]]<|/det|>
<form>I_{\mathrm{C}} = ..........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 761, 920, 780]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 791, 180, 809]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 790, 915, 841]]<|/det|>
Calculate \(R_{\mathrm{C}}\), the combined resistance of the resistor and the lamp connected in series, using the equation \(R_{\mathrm{C}} = \frac{V_{\mathrm{C}}}{I_{\mathrm{C}}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[566, 878, 920, 898]]<|/det|>
<form>R_{\mathrm{C}} = .......................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 687, 91]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will investigate the image produced by a lens. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 576, 121]]<|/det|> Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 3.1. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 128, 866, 273]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 288, 534, 307]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 319, 144, 339]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 319, 729, 339]]<|/det|> Place the lens a distance \(u = 20.0 \text{cm}\) from the illuminated object. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 351, 777, 369]]<|/det|> * Move the screen until a clearly focused image is formed on the screen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 381, 777, 400]]<|/det|> * Measure the distance \(v\) between the centre of the lens and the screen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 413, 180, 432]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 413, 376, 432]]<|/det|> Record \(v\) in Table 3.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 413, 920, 432]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 444, 180, 463]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 443, 509, 463]]<|/det|> Calculate, and record in Table 3.1, \(\frac{u}{v}\) . <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 444, 920, 463]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 475, 178, 494]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 475, 855, 494]]<|/det|> Repeat the procedure for \(u = 25.0 \text{cm}\), \(u = 30.0 \text{cm}\), \(u = 35.0 \text{cm}\) and \(u = 40.0 \text{cm}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 475, 920, 494]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 507, 541, 524]]<|/det|> Table 3.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[334, 532, 663, 708]]<|/det|>
\(u/\text {cm}\)\(v/\text {cm}\)\(\frac {u}{v}\)
20.0
25.0
30.0
35.0
40.0

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the strengths of wires made from different metals by measuring the force required to break the wires.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 920, 166]]<|/det|>
The apparatus is shown in Fig. 4.1. A wire is held by a clamp at one end and a load is suspended from the other end. The load is increased until the wire breaks. The student takes all the necessary safety precautions.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[386, 175, 608, 343]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 358, 532, 376]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 390, 920, 422]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate the force required to break wires made from different metals. You are **not** required to do the investigation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 437, 420, 454]]<|/det|>
The following apparatus is available:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 469, 314, 484]]<|/det|>
clamps and stands

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 483, 524, 500]]<|/det|>
a selection of masses with a suitable hanger

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 500, 245, 514]]<|/det|>
metre rule

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 514, 547, 530]]<|/det|>
a selection of wires made from different metals.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 545, 907, 561]]<|/det|>
You can also use other apparatus and materials that are usually available in a school laboratory.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 575, 324, 592]]<|/det|>
In your plan, you should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 606, 134, 623]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 606, 680, 623]]<|/det|>
write a list of suitable metals for the wires you would investigate

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 638, 136, 655]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 638, 566, 655]]<|/det|>
explain briefly how you would do the investigation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 670, 138, 687]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 670, 591, 687]]<|/det|>
state the key variables that you would keep constant

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 701, 136, 719]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 701, 920, 733]]<|/det|>
draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how you would display your readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 747, 136, 764]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 747, 655, 764]]<|/det|>
explain how you would use the results to reach a conclusion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 576, 88]]<|/det|>
You may add to the diagram if it helps your explanation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 831, 119]]<|/det|>
You are **not** required to write about the safety precautions that the student should take.
